question: You gonna jump? Or are you just having a last look?
answer: I was just thinking that I never had a new pair of shoes till I was twelve.

question: It's no my fault I was born first. Besides, nobody ever sent me on an eight month vacation, so ease up on the sad sack stuff.
answer: It's not a vacation, it's private school.

question: I thought this was your dream come true.
answer: That's not why he's sending me.

question: Why then.
answer: Because it looks good. I'm just not like you. Ya know? I'm never going to go to Yale. I'm never going to be "William".

question: Nobody says you have to be like me.
I don't feel like driving. Okay?
Yes.
Look, I just better go. Goodbye Mom. I'll be okay.
Yes sir.
Yeah.
answer: Rick March. Who the hell are you?

question: Gieg, Chuck.
answer: Look, meet us out front when you're through. If they try to take anything away from you like Johnny Quest up there, just make a list and we'll have 'em send it down to the boat.

question: Whatever.
What's your problem?
Because I felt like it. What do you care?
Well, as soon as you grow some balls, let me know.
Ahoy there.
Albatross? Doesn't inspire a lot of confidence.
answer: Oh, on the contrary, the Albatross is considered a very good omen. It is said they embody the spirits of sailors passed on. It's very bad luck if you kill one. And dolphins too.

question: I'm Francis Boutillier. This is my son, Philip.
answer: I know. You're a day late. We keep a schedule aboard ship. Lives depend on it. Hello, Philip.

question: Your cable said you wouldn't be putting out until mid-October.
answer: As you can see, there's a lot to do.

question: Indentured servitude is not what my son had in mind.
answer: This is a working ship. Promptness is not a luxury, it's a necessity, as is the work to maintain her. Had we been ready, I can assure you we would have sailed.

question: And I would have expected compensation for my time and expense coming all the way down here.
answer: Happily, it all worked out... This time. Bill, take Philip below and help him find a bunk.

question: I'll be frank with you. This was his mother's idea. A romp through the Caribbean on a sailboat sounds more like a vacation than an education if you ask me.
answer: It will be more than that, I can promise you.

question: Take good care of my son.
answer: We'll do our best. You're welcome to say goodbye.

question: Fall off to port. Ease her around to a heading of northeast. Sing out when you're there.
Speak up boy!
Behold gentlemen. The power of the wind! Did we lose anybody?
Chart us a course for the windward side.
answer: That low passed through last night. May be a little bumpy out there.

question: Then keep your mouth shut. What's it going to be?
Sorry won't cut it. Survival means discipline and assimilation. There are no special cases here. Now, get going. Get up there. What are you blubbering about?
One hand in front of the other son. We'll do it together. Don't look down. Look in my eyes! Climb! We'll do it together.
You climb damn it, or so help me I'll haul you to the foretop by your diaper and leave you there!
Are you hating this?! Are you!
answer: I hate you, you son of a bitch!!!

question: No. Hate the fear inside of you! Climb like a man mister! Hate it! Hate it away. Hate your way up one more rung!! Do it right now!!
We're awfully quiet tonight. Something on your mind, George?
answer: I think you were too hard on Weathers.

question: You do?

I need to know what I'm working with; what their boundaries are. Their lives depend on it, and for that matter so does yours. We've got to bring them together. Make them a crew. We're as strong as our weakest link and I don't want to find that out the hard way. So, I will challenge them and they will come together.

You know the best thing about being a Skipper is the worst thing. It's all my responsibility. So I'll tell you what George, you stay off of my bridge, and I'll stay out of your galley. We'll get along that way.
How ya doing?
Good.
answer: Look, I appreciate, you know, the concern and all, but like he said, I can take care of myself.

question: I just brought you something to eat. I feel like I got you into this.
I'm used to spending a lot of time alone. I guess that's what I thought it would be out here. But, it's not is it?
answer: I'm sorry I left you hanging up there.

question: It doesn't matter. Really. I'm just sorry you got chewed out.
answer: My brother and I used to climb to the top of this old beech tree in the back yard and watch the moon come up just like this. My parents would fight all the time so we'd sneak out there where we couldn't hear 'em and recite scenes from our favorite movies. Would you believe I miss it? The middle of paradise and I'm homesick.

question: Come in.
answer: Skipper, uh, the crew is pretty much doing group boot over the side.

question: Well, that's all part of it.
answer: We've got weather moving in from the west.

question: That's part of it, too.
Uh, huh.
answer: Would you, um, say it's a big storm?

question: I'll go.
answer: Bring it down and run up the storm jib. We'll fix it later. Stay out of reach of the blocks! Well, we're in it now.

question: NOOO!!!
Release this when I tell you!! NOW!!!
I mean she looks pretty damn good in her all-together for being thirty.
Trust me donut. I know.
So I'm standing there and you could hear a pin drop. No breathing or snoring... Suddenly it hits me that somethin' was goin' on that just stopped, really fast, like people are holding their breath.
My mother says in this really low, but very awake kind of voice "What?"
It was a bad dream...
Here's the thing; whenever you're having a nightmare, all you have to do is say 1-2-3 wake up! You'll be out of it. You'll wake up.
My dad.
Swear to God. Only good advice he ever gave me. Now, go back to sleep. You okay now?
answer: That's how he died you know.

question: Who?
answer: My brother. He fell out of the old beech tree. Broke his neck. I was on a camp out. They started going at it, throwin' things, a real knock down... They didn't find him 'till the next morning. They didn't even know why he was up there.

question: Jesus, you never told them?
Immortality.
answer: Spirits have a way of bringing that out.

question: And being sixteen.
answer: They're in a hurry to grow up. They don't know about consequences or responsibility. That's being sixteen too. I promise you one thing...

question: What's that?
answer: They'll know about it in the morning.

question: Yeah, well you're really gonna have some bad dreams if we find out you didn't.
How the hell are we gonna get outta here?
Oh, praise the lord. Relax everybody. Everything is under control. The jug head's going to think of something.
I cheated to get on the boat!!! All right?!
I doctored my grades so I'd make the cut. I'm a moron, okay? You satisfied?!
Well, we thought we'd drop in and see if you were all still in one piece.
Well, you never can tell these days, can you?
answer: What is it we can do for you today?

question: What's wrong, you don't like steak?
answer: I should be eating with the crew.

question: Humor me. Eat it anyway.
answer: Why are you here? I don't need you spying on me.

question: Spying?!
answer: I can take care of myself.

question: Oh, really?
answer: Look, you put me on this boat in the first place. I didn't want to come but I did. Why do you have to embarrass me. Why can't you just leave me alone?

question: Listen to me, you thankless little prick. We're your parents, so don't you dare talk to me disrespectfully. What the hell is it, this captain? Because I'll see him in a rowboat...
answer: It has nothing to do with him.

question: Well, what does it have to do with? Us?
answer: No. Look, it's me okay? Can't it just be about me? For once?

question: He would have loved this.
All his years at sea, he never stopped talking about these islands.
Every hour. Every minute. I wish he was here. I wish he could have sailed our girl. Seen these boys... I'd have liked to have said goodbye.
You sound so sure.
He never would have believed a woman like you existed.
answer: Do you remember the last time you and I danced under the stars?

question: Guilty.
answer: On the deck of the Yankee, the night you asked me to marry you. We weren't much older than they are.

question: What? Wait for me okay. I'll be right back. I swear. Phil. What are you doing?
answer: Fandango, Junior. I'm gonna do some limbo baby!!

question: No way Phil. Not like this.
answer: Roger Meris, steps up, it's a corker down the pipe... It's outta here!

question: Like you really care. Like any of you give a shit what happens to me.
answer: You're the one who doesn't care, Phil.

question: It hurts too much to care.
Come. What's on your mind?
answer: I'm here on behalf of the crew, sir.

question: Well, spit it out.
answer: The fact is... We'd like you to give Phil another chance.

question: Can't do it.
Close the door. Sit down. Why do you think I'm sending him home?
The Dolphin was a symptom.
Of a fight he can't win out here.
answer: It's his father sir. He's suffocating him. We've all seen it... I mean he has all these expectations and he doesn't even know who his own kid is. What right did then have to show up here?

question: They have every right Chuck.
answer: They send us because they want us to change, or grow up or something and then they try to keep us the same.

question: Let me tell you something about Phil's father, and your's too. How do you think you got here? You think this is all free, that they owe you something? You think they enjoy riding subways and commuter trains, driving buses or pulling lobster traps? Work fifty weeks a year to keep you in tennis shoes and private school? Look around at how the rest of the world lives Chuck. We're the luckiest people alive, every one of us. They gave it up for you and Phil, and me too my friend. There are ground rules in families just like on this boat. If you and Phil don't like it, I'm sorry. Someday you'll understand that, and if you're lucky, you'll come home and find your best friend has been there all along waiting for you to forgive him for being a father. It'll be the way it used to be, when you were ten and your dad was a giant. Does Phil know how you guys feel?
You should tell him. That's something he can take with him. I'm all ears.
answer: You may not like what you hear.

question: I can take it.
answer: They've become what you wanted. They're a crew. That's why he came.

question: Why did we begin this?
Because we believed we could make an impact out here. Self reliance and community through the disciplines of sailing.
Phil, he's not looking inside. He's just striking out at the world.
answer: He has a lot of hurt inside him.

question: Well, he better learn to own it. Actions have consequences. It's not what happens here Alice, it's what they take away with them.
Bill drop everything. Do it now! Who the hell do they think they are?
answer: They want us to identify ourselves.

question: Tell them we're the American School Ship, Albatross.
answer: They think we're carrying Cuban refugees. Skipper, they mean to board us.

question: Not a chance. Remind them that according to the Geneva Convention, firing on a civilian vessel on the high sea is an act of war.
answer: They say they are acting on the direct authority of Fidel Castro.

question: No. Bring him on deck with the others.
answer: Chicken is a fool's game captain.

question: So is violating international law.
Your cannons made a compelling argument.
He left his passport in Curacao. It's being mailed to Panama.
answer: That is unfortunate. We'll have to take him with us.

question: You okay?
Ninety-six.
What about you? It's a ninety-one! It's an 'A'!
You know? Then why are you up here looking like you're about to jump overboard?!
This is your moment, don't you see? The instant when you know that your life is never going to be the same again. When you stand up and are counted.
answer: I couldn't have done it without you.

question: Yes you could. You did. This is all you. Nobody else.
Feels different doesn't it?
That we're going back. I don't want it to end. I don't want to be what I was when I left.
Anonymous. I've been getting ninety-sixes my whole life. It's what they expect. After all this, I still haven't figured it out.
Who I am, outside of this boat. What the hell I'm doing here.
answer: I'll tell you who you are. You're the glue. You're the thing that holds everybody around you together. You're strong, you listen and you see things in people the rest of us can't. It's a gift.

question: You know, I never had friends like this.
I feel like... we can do anything.
Raise your sail, Bill. North, north- east. Keep a sharp look out for Florida.
answer: Maybe we could wait around a little longer, sir...

question: She's gone... She's gone. Carry on.
Chuck! Chuck!!!
I couldn't bring her down here until I knew you were safe. Come on. I thought we'd find a store, get you fixed up and then get you some lunch. That sound good?
I'm sorry, son. Are you okay? Why don't you go and try some of that on?
How're you doing in there?
All right. I'm gonna wander over and look at some shoes...
Chuck!!
answer: When we were growing up I always felt like you would take care of things, that everything would be okay. But you can't make this okay, can you?

question: There are allegations questioning your competence with regard to the command of the Albatross. I have been instructed to convene a formal tribunal to determine whether or not negligence played a part in the sinking.
May I ask you something? How'd you manage to piss off a guy as powerful as Francis Boutillier?
I used to helm a school ship. A long time ago.
answer: The Coast Guard 'Eagle'. She never lost a race while you were Skipper.

question: That's right, we didn't. I miss it sometimes. But, there are other things a Skipper can do. The families... want your ticket. Turn it in, we forget the whole thing. Everybody goes home.
The papers are going to eat you alive. Even if you beat it, you'll never get another commission. They want someone to be accountable.
Just tell 'em what we know and be done with it. That's what he'd want.
What's that supposed to mean?!
answer: Everybody knows why she went over Tod. You jibed the boat.

question: I was trying to get her up wind! That's what you do when you're hit a-beam. Or maybe you're too stupid to know that!
answer: That's not what Skipper thought. He was trying to spill air from the main!

question: It's okay. I'll be in, in a minute. Look, what do you want?
answer: Everybody's saying this whole tribunal is happening because of your father. Because of you.

question: Well that's just typical isn't it?
I gotta go.
answer: You weren't there, you don't know what happened.

question: I know enough.
answer: Phil, please. It won't change anything. Tell him to call it off.

question: Why didn't you drop any sail?
answer: Skipper called us out of the rigging.

question: But your instinct was to lose sail?
answer: My instinct was to not get electrocuted.

question: How old are you, son?
Had you ever seen a "White Squall" before this incident?
What makes you so sure it was one?
You really felt that your crew were up for the conditions.
answer: We'd come twelve thousand miles together, through every kind of seas imaginable...

question: Except, a "White Squall". With all due respect Captain Sheldrake, they're only boys...
answer: They are much more than that, sir.

question: Is it true that the reason you expelled Philip Boutillier...
... and that you invited him to strike you? To fight it out on the deck of your ship?!
Do you think this is funny? Some kind of joke? You lost six people out there.
answer: I don't think one second of this is funny, sir.

question: I have no more questions at this time. Oh, one last thing... Isn't true that your father was a sea Captain?
It's me, don't you see. Terry's right, I'm the escape hatch. I disobeyed order.
answer: You taking the order wouldn't have changed anything.

question: They don't know that. We were the only one's on deck. Look, there's nothing they can do to me right? I'm a kid.
That is the point... And Skipper'll slip off the hook.
answer: Why didn't you turn hard to port as the wind hit?

question: I thought we'd have a better chance if I headed into the wind so we could spill air from our sails.
answer: But the Captain ordered you hard to starboard.

question: Twice.
answer: Is that what you were trained to do?

question: No.
answer: Then what do you think he was trying to do.

question: Let the blow drive the boat down wind. Neutralize our canvas.
answer: So when the captain gave you an order contrary to your training, you thought he was making a mistake?
